Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrated Arctic Data Management Services (IADS) to Support Arctic Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: This is an effort to address the growing and increasingly diverse data management needs of the NSF arctic research community. Core activities of an Integrated Arctic Data Management Services (IADS) will include identifying and cataloging all data produced by NSF arctic investigators and providing assistance and tools to meet requirements to publish data and associated metadata. IADS will ensure that data are well documented to guarantee preservation and to promote interdisciplinary reuse, and it will enable data discovery through diverse portals, including a new IADS portal for publishing investigator metadata and data, special project support, and access by the broad community. IADS will foster scientific synthesis through its support services and help-desk functions, and by enabling integration of datasets stemming from NSF projects with data generated through activities of other U.S. agencies and other countries. The IADS will tackle the complexity of data types emerging from the Study of Environmental Arctic Change (SEARCH), the Arctic Observing Network (AON) and other efforts to serve diverse stakeholder needs. Along with advanced search and discovery capabilities, the IADS will include services such as reformatting (re-projection of gridded data, point to grid conversions, options to download data in a variety of formats), subsetting and visualization. Visualization services will include demos and instructions on how to use Integrated Data Viewer, Google Earth and other tools.

Broader Impacts: The core operation of this activity represents broader impacts. IADS will make its data holdings discoverable and usable, promote scientific synthesis and foster interagency collaboration crucial to meeting SEARCH objectives. Through activities and coordination with SEARCH/AON leadership via workshops and other venues, data management will be elevated to an integral part of scientific research. Support of groups before they go to the field will include metadata education, instruction on how to organize a data set before publishing, and provision of software tools to take to the field. The rewards of these various activities will be better data stewardship, services and data integration capabilities to benefit the arctic research community in coming years and decades.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Advanced Cooperative Arctic Data and Information Service (ACADIS) has supported all investigators funded through the National Science Foundation (NSF) Division of Polar Programs (PLR) Arctic Sciences Section (ARC) for over eight years, beginning in 2008. The ACADIS team was a collaboration among people with experience handling Arctic and other cryospheric datasets and those with specific data management expertise. The team came from the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) Earth Observing Laboratory (EOL), the NCAR Computational Information Systems Laboratory (CISL), the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC), and the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) Unidata Program.

The ACADIS long-term goal was to provide sustainable data management, data stewardship services and related data management leadership for the NSF Arctic research community. This was accomplished through open data sharing, adherence to best practices and standards, engagement with the community, and capitalizing on appropriate evolving technologies.  ACADIS development and support has allowed NSF/PLR/ARC to meet the increasing priority of data management in discovery science and to set a high standard for the stewardship of the crucial data needed to answer questions about the changes now underway in the Arctic.

ACADIS developed out of a necessity expressed in the Arctic Observing Network (AON) design to develop and implement a comprehensive data management strategy. This was an important component of NSF’s contribution to the International Polar Year (IPY) of 2007-2008. In response, the Cooperative Arctic Data and information Service (CADIS), a precursor to ACADIS, was initiated in 2007. CADIS was a collaboration between NCAR, NSIDC and UCAR. It was designed with the goal of facilitating data discovery and use by encouraging the standardization and exchange of metadata through an Information Technology (IT) structure that interoperated with web services and applications.

Realizing that the needs addressed by CADIS extended beyond AON, the CADIS collaborators submitted a proposal to expand services to support all Arctic investigators submitting data to NSF/PLR/ARC, thus developing an “Advanced CADIS” or ACADIS. The ACADIS team developed a web-based Gateway with customized, automated web-based submission tools for data, metadata and documentation. The ACADIS Gateway supported researchers with tools and services for preserving, citing and sharing research data. Improvements were made to these services as feedback was received from the community.

A hallmark of ACADIS was providing a high level of support to the user community. ACADIS Community Support provided individualized consulting for metadata, data, and documentation creation and submission for the complete data lifecycle (proposal through data collection, archival and long-term stewardship). The ACADIS team made a priority of participating in a variety of national and international meetings, workshops, and targeted community gatherings (70 in the period from early 2014 until early 2016) to keep the Arctic community informed about the data management support and training afforded through ACADIS.

The ACADIS data legacy includes more than 3600 datasets archived together with ISO standard 19115 metadata and documentation. Figure 1 summarizes the growth of datasets archived in ACADIS from 2008  to 2016.  One of the more important and flexible components of the ACADIS system was the ability to accept data in a variety of formats (more than 60) representing more than 50 scientific disciplines.

The ACADIS Gateway enabled scientists, students, and the public to explore, discover, access and download data collected by more than 400 contributing investigators representing more than 210 NSF grant awards.  Figure 2 provides a summary of metrics associated with ACADIS.  This was an archive with international interest, steadily increasing monthly use and remarkable disciplinary diversity.  Another ACADIS component was the Arctic Data Explorer, available online as a broad discovery tool for finding and accessing interdisciplinary Arctic data from diverse investigators, projects, agencies, and nations in repositories scattered around the world.

More than 640 publication references have been logged by ACADIS, including 519 research publications, 9 books, 95 conference proceedings, 3 Special Journal issues, and 8 graduate school theses and dissertations. In the final analysis, these publications combined with the data that were used to generate the results is the remarkable legacy of Arctic research for more than a decade. The ACADIS team has been honored to support the Arctic community for this period of time.

There are several important lessons learned from more than 8 years of ACADIS support. Cutting edge technology does not always lead to useful stable tools. It is critical to understand what the community needs are and then match them to available technologies.  New development is possible. It comes at a cost.  There is a trade-off between keeping up with rapidly changing technology and providing stable, long-term community support. Communication between collaborating partners can be challenging and should not be underestimated. User support must focus on the education of data providers and users.  At the end of this project’s lifetime, transition planning was critical to assure the long-term stewardship of this national resource.
